node.title: Is Democracy’s Fate the Media’s Fault?
node.description: How should political journalists be approaching their work in these polarized times?
node.content: ["With the midterms just months away and the 2024 presidential race around the corner, the press is gearing up to cover more deeply polarizing election cycles.", "And how it should do that is an equally polarizing question. The media\u2019s role in preserving \u2014 and reporting on \u2014 our democratic institutions is up for discussion.", "Last week, the New York Times Opinion columnist Ross Douthat pushed back on media critics like the N.Y.U. associate professor Jay Rosen. Jay asserts that the press should strive to be \u201cpro-truth, pro-voting, anti-racist, and aggressively pro-democracy.\u201d", "Ross disagrees, claiming that such a stance could feed more polarization.", "[You can listen to this episode of \u201cThe Argument\u201d on Apple, Spotify or Google or wherever you get your podcasts.]", "So, this week Jane Coaston invited Ross and Jay to the show for a lively debate over how the press should cover politics in a democratic society.", "(A full transcript of the episode will be available midday on the Times website.)"]
